tossups.question: A poem by this author states that ‘Certainty, fidelity / On the stroke of midnight pass / Like vibrations of a bell’ and asks the addressee to ‘Lay your sleeping head [...] human on my faithless arm’. In another poem, this author described seeing the title geographical feature ‘when I try to imagine a faultless love / Or the life to come’ and feeling ‘consistently homesick for’ the title landscape ‘chiefly / Because it (*) dissolves in water’. This author depicted ‘Crav[ing] [...] Not universal love / But to be loved alone’ in a poem which claims that ‘Exiled Thucydides knew / All that a speech can say / About Democracy’. That poem by this author of “In Praise of Limestone” opens in a dive ‘on Fifty-second Street’ and famously declares that ‘We must love one another or die’. For 10 points, name this gay Anglo-American poet of “September 1, 1939”.

This person was the founder-president of the ill-fated frozen orange juice company Citri-Frost. While at university, this person and Albert Upton founded the Orthogonian Society, whose contrast with the Franklin Society is used to shape a book about this person by Rick Perlstein. While on a visit to Caracas, this person’s car was attacked, an event which shaped their promotions of Vernon Walters. This person smeared Helen (*) Douglas as a Communist sympathiser with the Pink Sheet, doggedly pursued Alger Hiss, and also made Elvis Presley an honorary member of the DEA. Notoriously appearing sweaty in one TV appearance, in an earlier speech this person defended their financial conduct, saying that their wife did not own a mink coat, but that they intended to keep one gift, the dog Checkers. For 10 points, name this US president who resigned after the Watergate scandal.

Two decades after one of their best-known paintings, this artist painted a sequel to it as a large mural over three arches in the Barnes Foundation. After a trip to Morocco, a figure ‘with raised arms’ was painted by this non-Ingres artist as part of their 1920s series of paintings of oriental chambermaids. After a sculpture this artist was working on smashed, they were inspired by a trip to Algeria to paint a nude subtitled for ‘memory of (*) Biskra’. A woman has her hair in a bun in front of a multicoloured background, while the title feature divides her face, in a work by this painter which was exhibited with works by his followers like Maurice de Vlaminck. This painter’s wife Amelie appears in their works Woman with a Hat and The Green Stripe, and one of their best-known works depicts five nudes holding hands in a circle. For 10 points, name this French Fauvist painter of The Dance.

Branch point twist fields were invented to aid the computation of measures of this phenomenon. For one- dimensional gapped QFTs this property of an interval obeys an ‘area law’. One measure of this property for a bipartite subsystem involves a trace norm and a partial transpose; that measure is called logarithmic negativity and unusually can be zero for some (*) non-separable states. This property is often described by the second Renyi entropy and LOCC operations do not increase this property. This property occurs whenever a pure state of a combined system is not a product state, and the four Bell states are said to have this property ‘maximally’. EPR pairs are states with this property that can be used for ‘quantum communication’. For 10 points, name this phenomenon that Einstein famously described as ‘spooky action at a distance’.
tossups.answer: quantum entanglement [accent entanglement entropy, logarithmic negativity, Renyi entropy before mention.] <JR>

tossups.question: This element can be isolated as a molecule that until recently was thought to contain a quintuple bond, with the only known example of a phi bond. A D8h analogue of ferrocene contains this element sandwiched between two 8-haptic cyclo-octa-tetra-enide anions. This element forms a linear cation with oxygen that contains two triple bonds, as a result of the hydrolysis of its solvated (*) 6+ cation. Nitrates and acetates of that cation are used as a stain in electron microscopy, and this element is present in a fluorescent glass used since antiquity. This element’s hexafluoride undergoes gaseous diffusion or centrifugation as part of an enrichment process, and yellowcakes are processed from this element’s ores, which include pitchblende. For 10 points, name this heaviest common naturally occurring element, whose 235 isotope is used in fission reactors.

bonuses.leadin: A vigilante campaign in this novel is joined by Younger Brother, who contributes his explosives knowledge. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this historical fiction novel whose real-life characters include Evelyn Nesbit and Booker T. Washington. Father dies on the sinking Lusitania in this novel by E. L. Doctorow.

In Ragtime, this character’s car is vandalised by a racist fire crew. As a result, this character launches a protest, and is joined by a number of angry young men who all refer to themselves with this character’s name.
Violent and destructive firemen also feature in this novel, in which they destroy books. This Ray Bradbury novel is titled for the temperature at which book paper catches fire.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about the use of the D-S-C-H motif by people who weren’t Shostakovich. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this composer, who repeated the motif in the organ in “For I am under the same accusation with my Saviour” from their cantata Rejoice in the Lamb. This composer also wrote operas like Albert Herring and Peter Grimes.
This composer used the D-S-C-H motif in their Cadenza for Solo Violin, and used a transposition of it, together with the BACH motif, in the tone row of their St Luke Passion.

Ronald Stevenson wrote a giant piano work titled for this musical form based around the motif. The third movement of Shostakovich’s Violin Concerto No. 1 is in this form, as is the fourth of Britten’s Sea Interludes from Peter Grimes.

bonuses.leadin: One member of this family, Richard, was known as the Red Earl, and dominated Ireland outside of the Pale for more than 35 years from 1280 onwards. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Irish noble family, who established themselves as Earls of Ulster until their power was shattered by a 1315 Scottish invasion. An English chief justiciar from this family defeated the fleet of the pirate Eustace the Monk early in Henry III’s reign.
That Scottish invasion was led by Edward, the younger brother of this person, who was Richard De Burgh’s son-in-law. This person had earlier murdered someone else known as ‘the Red’, John Comyn.

Before he was killed, Edward Bruce was the last person to claim this title. Through Aoife [EE-fa] MacMurrough, the Bruces were distantly related to Brian Boru who had held this position 300 years previously.
answers: : Robert the Bruce [or Robert I; prompt on partial answer]
: High King of Ireland [prompt on partial answers]
